posts.com:
Advice on making a successful advice post on /o/:

If you are looking to get advice on a possible car purchase or car related problem, be sure to include:

What car or cars you are looking at or as detailed a description of the problem as possible. Include make, model, year, mileage, condition, any know faults, the asking price, and what your budget is!

If people have to ask you for every detail, you aren't going to get many replies!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
1.)Get financing ahead of time/know your credit. You always want to have a financing option in hand before you go to a dealership. Nothing wrong with negotiating a better deal with them once you get there, but never go in empty handed. This way you can have idea of how much you can afford to spend, and what a car is going to cost you

2.)Do your research. Know what values KBB/NADA/Edmunds/TrueCar are listing for the cars you are interested in. Also know what other dealerships are listing similar cars for. Dealerships will prey on the uninformed, so make sure that you are

2b.)If you don't know enough about cars to inspect one yourself, arrange to get any used car inspected or bring someone who DOES know what to look for. It's surprisingly easy to polish up a turd and get it passed inexperienced eyes

3.)Never take the first offer, unless it's a place like CarMax that doesn't negotiate. Dealerships know the game, and they always get a certain number of people to bite on the first offer. make them work a little to get your business

4.)You can negotiate on more than the price. Oil changes, services plans, warranties, accessories are all fair game.

5.)In today's world, internet sales departments are your friend. You can send a blanket email to 3 or 4 dealerships and get them to compete for your business, let them haggle with each other before you ever haggle with them

6.)Get them to print you a Buyers Order for any car you are seriously, that is what you negotiate from. It will look like pic related, and itemize every line of the sale. Don't let them 4 square you or hand write shit on a piece of paper. Get a buyers order

7.)Never be afraid to walk away from a deal. If you have a bad feeling, sleep on it. There will always be other cars

posts.com:
More contact = less chance of slipping
therefore
Less contact = less rolling resistance
More force therefore means more chance of slipping, which means there is a sweet spot of how much contact you need before rolling resistance eats up the gains.

Except its not that straight forward, since tires are 'soft' 3D geometrical objects and in 99% cases pneumatic.
Pattern, seip and tire deformation works independently of this. You also have hydroplaning and the more common variant: Steamplaning.

The even simpler answer is that in racing you can get away with slicks so long you are driving in optimal conditions, and are willing to make slicks expandable by stopping to use them when they start deforming incorrectly.
Tires have seip and groves so the material don't need to be as soft in order to deform to correctly keep surface contact for friction.

>>26314302
For a simplified model of car tire grip the equation
Normal Force x coefficient of friction = friction is true
However, a tires coefficient of friction is load sensitive. As you press down harder on the tire you get less grip out of it. So all other things being equal spreading out weight of the car over more surface area will result in a higher coefficient of friction, leading to more grip.

posts.name: fujiwarastickershop.jp
posts.com:
>>26274024
I'll reiterate a couple of points and add on a few things from the last time I talked about it, a large reason we didn't want to work on it is because of the aforementioned but there's a large list of things that piled on top of one another and we just don't feel like doing it anymore.

- We're spending money on production that could be used for that sticker on other products instead. Pre-orders are gone, and we don't want to create a 6 week lead time (pre-order + production).

- I worked briefly with desuprint who informed me of issues with production, a large one being that Taiyo works in Inkscape primarily and the design would have to be completely rebuilt in Illustrator along with the white ink layer. desuprint also had the foil we wanted to do it on, however he has told me a while ago he is unable to reproduce it. The cost in paying him to print the stickers would be exploiting and underpaying him, or it would end up charging the customer out the ass. Paying over $10 for a sticker is stupid, and that's ironic because my store will only offer tracked shipping in the future and I apologize for any international orders because shipping is literally going to eat people's asses.

- Many things have been on my backlog for a while. In the past 6 months, nearly every original Taiyo design has been under renovation along with new(er) projects. I reflected over my FOTM drop and figured it wasn't something I wanted to force myself to do like I did before after Grandmasterslices gave me input that made me realize I was pushing myself way too hard and getting frustrated over nothing.

tl;dr no thanks, see you when the store is open someday.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26308415
I daily my NB and it's great. It's comfortable (stock) and the trunk is adequate for grocery trips. I would not recommend dailying such an old car for people who don't wrench themselves, not sure if you do. I wouldn't want to hand it off to a non-car person like wives tend to be until you've gone through it and replaced old rubber parts like brake hoses, calipers, hard/cracked coolant/vacuum hoses, suspension bushings and joints, etc to minimize failure points that could leave her stranded. Luckily NA/NB is piss easy to work on and all the upgrades you could ever think of are well documented online like at miata.net, if you can think of something you'd want to do to it or had a problem, someone has already tried it out/fixed it and made a forum post about it. The NB is a much better car to live with in every way (and cheaper), but if you're set on an NA for the flippy lights I'd understand. I don't think you'll need any backup camera stuff, the visibility with the top up is pretty good and with the top down you can see absolutely everything. The low beltline really helps.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26308415
>anything to look out for
rust
oil leaking/seeping. is an expensive fix. like, may as well swap the fucking engine. it will be burning oil at this point, nothing you can do to fix
rust
do a compression test
rust
>upgraydez
Chassis bracing. Cowl, frame rail, and butterfly braces. NAs were noodly when new, never mind after 30 years, and wifey will wonder why her kyuuuute new car rides like it's broken
if your summers get hot, the engine may need help keeping cool, particularly cylinder 4, which runs hotter than the rest because Mazda was retarded when putting the B engines into the Miata and couldn't be fucked to fix it over the NA/NB's lifetime. You might be able to get away with just radiator cowling to help the shitty airflow, otherwise it's time for better radiator and fan + cooling reroute
>hard top
Make sure to get a car with an OEM top already attached, otherwise you're in for a long and annoying hunt for a used top (good luck finding one under $2k), or spending $4.3k at cox mazda and waiting a year for a new one. They're big theft targets, too, and bolting them down properly makes them that much more annoying to take off. The non-OEM tops aren't great for street use and need additional finishing from a body shop or someone who knows their shit in order to fit well
>brakes
you don't really need to upgrade them unless you're doing trackdays
>backup camera
lol why
>fancy radio
install additional soundproofing if you go this route, otherwise there's no point
>heat and ac
the heater will probably work too well, AC will likely need some help, tho the hardtop will help keep the cold air in. Put heat shielding around the transmission tunnel between the tunnel and body, and maybe between carpet and body. Make sure the evap coil is clean, and if it still sucks, replace the condenser

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26308565
If the rest of the car is decent, it is a fair price today but I personally wouldn't because straightening out that metal could be a PITA and a bit of a gamble.
It could be as easy as removing the fender, hammering out the underlying structure, and finding a used fender (they've all got rust where they attach to the bumper). But also it could require replacing the underlying metal and you'd need to find a donor and weld it in. Finding the plastic headlight surround is easy, aftermarket. Straightening the US bumper shouldn't be too bad; if the strut's ruined you can always do a "bumper tuck" by drilling the struts out and compressing the diving board bumper in.
The company that makes rust repair panels doesn't offer anything for this part of the car: https://www.millsupply.com/search.php?k=mercedes%20240d&e=7959&s=Mercedes,W123%20Chassis&page=1
Also 240Ds are slow, I'd want at least a 300D. If the 240d is automatic I'd hard pass.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26310660
W140 SLS
worst case scenario:
2 replacement SLS struts - $1400ea from MB, $500-600ea direct from Sachs (OE supplier), or $500/pair from china
2 replacement hydraulic nitrogen spheres - $90ea OEM
3 bottles of SLS fluid - $12ea
Cheapskate scenario:
Replacement shock top rubber isolation mount: $100ea
DIY conversion of failure prone lower spherical bearing to a regular bushing: <$100 to do both sides. OR, these guys sell a bushing conversion for $100 each side: https://rebuildmastertech.com/mercedes-benz-s-class-w140-1992-1998-oe-new-suspension-rear-left-right-shock-absorber-bushing-1403209313/
Alternative cheapskate scenario
Buy a pair of 2 used good condition struts for ~$200 and do your best to keep the lower spherical bearings greased excessively so they don't rust
It's the same fundamental setup as on the W123, and W123 guys are already rebuilding old SLS shocks; it's just a matter of time before it's done for the W140. The hydraulic part never really fails, it's that the top rubber isolation mounts fail and the lower spherical bearing rusts and squeaks (picrel).
tl;dr: full SLS service can be $3,000 in parts or $400; it just depends how you go about it and how creative you want to be.

NEVER BEFORE DOCUMENTED FIX for BECKER 1492 erratic volume knob
The faceplate can be removed with 4 tabs and 1 T8 screw. The board can be removed with tabs and 2 T8 screws. The rotary encoder can be desoldered at 7 points, and opened up and cleaned with lectramotive electric parts cleaner. My radio volume knob now works like new.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

I also fixed several dim segments of the LCD display. The LCD was removed by bending its metal tabs that go through the board, and the strip of contacts was cleaned with lectramotive and a lint free microfiber cloth, and reassembled.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
For a while, I've had a book that lists every single Italian auto manufacturer. There's a brief section on OPES (Officine di Precisione E Stampaggio), the first new manufacturer in post-war Italy. Their only car, the Ninfea, was a FWD sedan that came with a 702cc or 784cc 3 cylinder engine. After a prototype was made in Turin in 1946, it was showcased at an auto show there in 1948. They obtained 100 orders, but financial issues caused the company to fold before they could fulfill any of them.

The only images online of it seem to come from a single brochure. Of the handful of examples made, I don't think any are extant.

>>26275735
No. It wasn't even a real serial production - it was an initiative research project by some engineers and designers of Central Scientific Research Automobile and Automotive Engines Institute (NAMI for short). Six cars that they made remained in their personal posession. All of them had air cooled V4 at the rear from different ZAZ models.
There was a noticeable movement of self-made automobiles in USSR, with conventions and articles in tech journals like "Technics for the youth". One of the most prominent of the constructors and his son are hosting YT channels "Combat Crew" and "Combat Crew Live" which has detailed videos about their projects (most famous one, Laura, is on the pic), maybe you will be able to understand something with YT subtitles. Also, one of the most popular youtubers found one of the soviet self-made cars on sale, fixed it and made an interview with the old man who made it:
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLiCpP_44QZBz9D1Cp8f2Qp1auev7EKqpi

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Toyota Century Limousine made from 1989-1996 (almost all made before 92, only a few hundred made). The ultimate expression of the Japanese bubble economy excesses in a highly conservative and understated package.

A Toyota factory limo based on extending the rear doors and adding a mid segment to the VG40 Century. They came with an ice maker/drink cooler or heater and a glass set with decanter, TV that could receive terrestrial broadcasts with a VHS player, 12 disc CD changer, rear tape recorder that could also play tapes over the stereo system, glass divider with motorized curtain, rear window motorized curtain, drink cooler in the rear AC vent box, a remote that controlled the entire entertainment system and the HVAC for the rear passengers, all seats heated and massaging/ reclining rear seats as well as an interphone and options for a mobile phone for the driver and rear passengers and fax machine.

Car also featured a 4L all aluminum hemispherical pushrod V8 engine, rear air leveling, electronically adjusted shock valving and even automatically dimming headlights with a garage/dawn/dusk mode (parking lights only).

Yeah I know pound for pound and size for size round tubing will be stronger. I just went up in wall thickness to compensate and I think it's overkill as a result. Could have been a little lighter with round, but the bumper itself probably only weighs 80lbs. Lighter than most plate bumpers I bet.

It is plenty strong though, can jack both wheels up from the sliders and they've taken hits, been dragged across stumps and rocks, ect. Bumper is same tubing but with triangles.

My concern now is puncturing the oil pan/transmission pan as they're not covered protected with skids at the moment. Gas tank has a steel skid from factory, the rear diff casing is tough, but the oil pans are vulnerable.

In highschool I wanted a big Single Turbo Supra making 1000whp. I got to drive a RHD Supra, single turbo, making 350-400whp and it was dogshit. It felt like a sloppy Lexus Sedan with a shitty interior. It made boost at like 4800 rpm, and redline at 7200. 2400 rpm powerband, and it has absolutely nothing below 4500 rpm.

Another dude, co-worker, wants to make 500whp on his STI. But to go past 400whp, its recommended he builds the motor. And rhe shop told him (they specialize in Subarus) even then you can still have ring land failures, headgaskets, and other issues.

I then read this article and all updates building a VG30DETT https://motoiq.com/engine-tech-building-the-nissan-vg30dett-part-1/

The amount of work it takes to build an engine only capable of holding 850whp.

Why do people love JDM Cars soooo much?

American cars can make big power with ease. Euro cars feel so much better to drive. You can make an American Pony car handle well for not much money (tons of space for wide tires) and if you put the same work into a Euro car you can make big power with that as well.

>>26319019
The biggest problem with JDM fanboying is an outdated concept of reliability.

American cars took a reliability nosedive in the 70's and didn't come out of it until the late 80's or in some cases the early 90's. This was all due to emission shit that big V8s were burdened with while little shitter Japanese cars didn't need anything, so naturally the V8s suffered. Pretty much any 90's American sports car is as reliable if not more reliable than an equally powerful Japanese car. Only some shitter Corolla might edge out a Mustang, for example, but that's not apples to apples by a long shot.

All of the high end JDM cars are ticking time bombs unless you really pull out all the stops and spend 10's of thousands on mods. Even for handling the Japanese flagships were often boats full of unnecessary bullshit so handling is nothing special, either. The American cars also tend to have pretty comfy roomy engine bays vs. god awfully tight JDM engine bays on everything but front engine 4 cylinders. I can't believe how comparatively easy it is to get around a C5 or New Edge Mustang engine bay compared to most JDM cars.

I'm over it, personally. I only liked Japanese cars because everyone told me they were reliable and American cars weren't, but I'm quickly learning that all of that was outdated 30 years ago and they're fine if you remotely maintain them. Any real world reliability differences come down more to negligent owners that bought the American car because it was the cheapest in its class and never spent a penny on maintenance and ragged the hell out of it while some Corolla buyer went to every maintenance interval and never took it past 2/3 of the rev range.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26319019
The biggest blind spot I see consistently is the effect of regulations and taxes on vehicle design. People assume that a Japanese (or Euro) sports car that competes with an American car should basically have the same performance and qualities, as they are competitors. In reality, Japanese and Euro brands CAN'T compete with American sports cars because they are born from an entirely different legal world. Japs and Euros face stiff taxes on displacement and in some cases outright bans due to emissions bullshit. This means you either literally CAN'T make a V8 car or if you do it has to be so expensive due to taxes/fees that it is a luxury car by default. Consider a Mustang GT which in Netherlands costs something like $80k... if you're going to spend $80k on a car most people would rather pay $100k and have a non-dogshit interior, whereas adding that additional $20k in price to an American mustang (going from $40k to $60k) is a much different proposition. However, the other thing people don't realize is that comparing 0-60 times and such as if faster always means better is the definition of bench racing. In the real world these things aren't that important and they're just one part of the entire sports car experience.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Pennzoil NISMO GT-R invasion at 2001 NISMO FESTIVAL!

2001 was a rad year! It was a rare and unique opportunity to see all the Pennzoil-sponsored NISMO GT500 cars together. And let me tells you: the legendary american oil brand stopped to sponsor one of two NISMO official team chassis in 2000 JGTC season, but returned to 2001 for sponsor the ex-LOCTITE ZEXEL GT-R car, becoming the ‘Pennzoil ZEXEL GT-R’ that year. Different from the 1998 R33, and 1999 R34 Pennzoil GT500 champions, and even helping NISMO to win the 2001 season on team standings along with the sister chassis, the Pennzoil ZEXEL GT-R has been updated to ‘Castrol PITWORK GT-R’ for 2002, losing the yellow livery and the Pennzoil sponsor once again. So yes, it means that the Pennzoil ZEXEL GT-R is no longer around us.

Another curious fact, , is that the Pennzoil NISMO GT-R BCNR33 and BNR34 pictured here aren’t “original” cars, but replica based on other chassis. Respectively, they are the 1998 ZEXEL SKYLINE and 1999 CALSONIC SKYLINE repainted as Pennzoil-sponsored cars for NISMO’s heritage.

The original Pennzoil BCNR33 has the low-downforce kit and Nicos GT banner and sometimes can be seen appearing in some events, including the NISMO FESTIVAL itself. The original Pennzoil BNR34 however, has been lost. It was upgraded to ‘Castrol NISMO GT-R’ for 2000 JGTC season, but the car crashed in the first round, being replaced by a new bespoke chassis. NISMO took the IMPUL’s BNR34 late that year to replicate the 1999 JGTC GT500 drivers champion.

A historical racing team named French Speed Connection has bought a JLOC Murcielago and a Taisan Viper (can't remember which year), they're restoring them and plan to race them in the Endurance Racing Legends championship taking place around Europe.
Unfortunately most JGTC/Super GT cars have either been dismantled or stored in some warehouse/yard and collecting dust and/or rust. Sometimes they're put up for sale to free up room, or auctioned off (recent examples include the Jim Gainer 360/430, #666 Bomex Avanzza Vemac, one of the 986 Boxsters that ran in GT300). Another interesting case is the Dijon Racing GT300 Corvette, it ended up being converted to a drift car by Daigo Saito

posts.sub: Which is the best inexpensive daily commuter Mustang?
posts.com:
Usually the discussion is on "muh V8 with mawds", but I already have a C5 Corvette and a GSXR 600, so speed is covered, if I was to buy a Mustang I would be looking for fuel economy, reliability, serviceability, and just an overall good ownership experience.

Of the generations shown, which would be the best V6/Ecoboost Mustang to buy for $5000-$15000 to be a fuel efficient, reliable daily without a lot of bullshit (esp. expensive) problems and a big bonus for better than average handling if any generation provides that over the others.

Also, which of these generations has the most roomy back seat in coupe form? (not interested in convertibles). Were any of these generations ever offered in a hatch?

Assume I would buy from a Boomer that babied it and did all factory recommended servicing with probably 100-200k miles on it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26314322
The only real answer would be an Ecoboost mustang, and you'll be hard-pressed to find a decent one for under $15k. Only the S550 and up have IRS, you're going to be stuck with a solid rear axle car more suited for straight lines without some mods to the chassis otherwise. The V6s in the older Mustangs are also pretty solid and reliable, but fuel economy really isn't that great and is surprisingly comparable to the V8. Back seats also suck in every single one.
If your only other vehicles are a C5 and a Gixxer, I'd be looking at a bigger vehicle, something such as a wagon/truck/SUV that you could tow another car with and throw shit in the back of, or a roomy hatchback if you're just looking for a commuter to beat on.
A well kept, boomer owned low-mileage 2.3L Fox Body hatchback would probably be my choice, though. They're old enough to be cool classics even in non-V8 form, and get decent MPG for what they are with a relatively gutless 4-cylinder.
>t. owned a 2.3L Fox Body and a 3.8L New-Edge SN95

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Avoid 05-10 V6s unless you want to tear it down and then deal with the timing chain self destruction issues however those losers deal with it. I've seen plenty of 04 and older V6s with blown head gaskets but that's not really a death sentence if it happens, as long as you are ok with turning a wrench yourself it can be an option, and will be the cheapest option. 11 and newer V6s are the better 3.7. 2015 and newer you get IRS and the ecoboost is an additional option. Just don't put a horrible tune or do anything stupid to the ecoboost to make it unreliable.
From my experience 99-14 all have roomy backseats, 15 and newer has less headroom. Also somewhere around 2000 is when all the carseat latches started being put in the back, if you have children then that's a convenience worth keeping in mind. Owned sn95, new edge, s197 and s550 mustangs, always had a V8 though so anything related to rental fleet models is secondhand knowledge aside from the stuff universal between them all.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I had an Ecoboost and currently have a sick ass V8 mustang. Both S550s, the V8 in the refresh.

The EcoBoost is a perfectly fine and fun vehicle but understand what it isn't. The eco is better left with the stock tires but definitely get the ford tune. its $750 bucks and is warranty safe. You'll put out like 350hp or something like that which is just enough to have a good amount of fun with but not enough to really be a retard. That being said, you can be a retard with E85 tunes or throwing huge turbos on them. If you take care of it, don't mod except the ford tune, and diligently do 5k oil changes, you will have a great engine that lasts a long time. The bad things are it's not a V8 and every motherfucker you meet will ask you why you didn't get one so be prepared for that. Mileage is great on the road but okay in town. I averaged about 22-23 in town but that's with a heavy foot. On the road though, the eco is pretty badass. I averaged 45 mpg on a couple of trips to Vegas. its great at getting up to 85-90 and sitting there in cruise control and doesn't do any gay gear shit of having awkward rpms with cruise control. id get the automatic A10 not the manual in the eco. you will hold boost through the shift with the auto so no blowoff sounds really unless you paddle shift. don't bother with those stupid blowoff valve kits, you can disconnect the egr valve line ( I think its that one, or the one next to it) to get the same sound. I would definitely get rid of the resonator but keep the stock mufflers otherwise you'll sound like shit.

also, just buy the V8. If you plan on keeping it for a while, the V8's hold value a lot better but like other anons said, you aren't getting LSD unless you get an S550. Mileage in the GT is predictably crap in town, 15-18 depending on how obnoxious I am but decent on the highway, getting anywhere from 26-30 depending on speed.

Starting work with pic rel pretty soon as a company driver, I’m just genuinely curious as to why people give company drivers, cents per mile pay, among other things, a bad rap. Besides the obvious (mile shortages, Pay issues, harsh scheduling) is there anything that really makes this specific position so much worse then, let’s say, being an owner operator, and having to pay out the ass for General DOT fuckery?

And, if this is really the worst position, what is recommended? Im young, inexperienced, and broke with very little to no expenses besides bills n food.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26306665
>>A serious trucker has entered the chat

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26306734
Most company driver hate is memes, with some truth mixed in. In general, if you take pride in your work and learn the unspoken rules (like don't take your 30 in the fuel lane, and say no to flip flops) you will be ahead of 80% of the company drivers most are upset about.

Get your first year in, and immediately go find a company that pays better and doesn't hire students. You will almost always find your pay doubles.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26306827
How do most company positions feel about taking a girl along for extended period of time? I’m not talking about like, every once in a while, I mean more like 80 to 90% of my over the road time with girlfriend in passenger.

Should I just be doing local or dedicated (which I’m certain are very few with my experience and age) ?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26306869
Not him, but am familiar with the industry... Most companies allow a passenger to be brought along, but you should get their OK first though, for insurance purposes.

What sort of work you do is up to what you like. Some guys like highway, some guys like local. Highway is a good place to start though for the experience. I lasted about two years highway before the novelty wore off, and have only done various local work since then. I value home time more than I value an easy cruise down the highway. But I never regretted that time spent on the highway... I went to places that I would've never seen before, and got paid for it. Met some interesting characters along the way also.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26306827
>>26306889

I appreciate it. Just hoping May treats us good enough for our lives to get started. Ill see if I can’t convince them to let me run local after a year or so, like last reply said I value home time a lot as well.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26306979
You know it is what it is... It's not all bad really. The minute you're running for them means you're now in control of your own situation, being actively hired and trucking. If you don't smash up their shit on a regular basis, keep on trucking for them while enjoying new sights & smells, but start tossing out resumes to outfits like USPS if you want big pay with more home time. Or operate the concrete truck... I made good dollars operating the concrete mixer for a season. With experience under your belt, more options will open up.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26306979
I have a friend who started at May, functionally he said it was a good company, they keep you moving and treat you ok. The downside is the pay is low (for the industry) you will keep 6-700 a week.

But like i said above, get your year in, don't hit anything and you will double your salary when moving to a local/regional gig that requires experience. For instance, my brother runs fedex and is getting 1200/wk minimum guaranteed pay for fill in work.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26313862
>it shifts from one motor to two at 70mph
There's no shifting when the Volt switches motors. It does sometimes hand off propulsion to the smaller motor at highway speeds, but this is imperceptible to the driver. The only thing you might notice is a delay when passing because the larger motor has to take over. This can happen at any highway speed, not just 70 MPH. There's also a misconception that the engine makes a physical connection to the wheels at 70 MPH. This is also false. The engine makes a physical connection to the wheels whenever the vehicle deems it's more efficient. This includes high load scenarios like accelerating and cruising at high speed, though there's no strict speed at which this occurs.

>and you can feel it and then when the gas motor kicks in it's BRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRR and vibrates the whole car like a lawn mower.
Yes, the engine can still be heard and felt, but unlike a typical gas car, the engine is run far less (in some cases up to 90% less), resulting in a smoother and quieter experience for the rest of the time while driving on electricity.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26314270
Even if you did use some gas miles every time you drove, you'd still be at a net savings over a Prius for a relatively long distance. If you drove 38 miles (using up all the electric range) then drove 37 more miles (burning one gallon of gas) you'd achieve a total efficiency of 75 MPG, significantly better than a standard Prius. While electricity might have come at a cost, it's typically much cheaper or even free depending on your living situation.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26315947
Prior to about 2005 or so, automatics were usually 4 speed (3 or even 2 if you go back to the 80's and before) slushboxes that were terrible off the line, slow to shift, and had really wide ratios that kicked you out of the powerband. They required regular fluid changes, usually only lasted 100k before needing a rebuild, and got worse MPG than a manual.

On the other hand, manuals were 5 or 6 speed with close ratios and a fuel economy gear at the top so they'd get great highway MPG, could be launched at higher RPM (without drag modifications and the shitty drivability that comes with them), and stayed in the powerband better. As long as you could manage the clutch and shifter, the car was all around better. My first car was a 6 speed manual and I could dust cars well above my price bracket with automatics all day long.

Nowadays, the autos are faster at the drag strip and track while getting better MPG and sometimes even lasting longer between services/replacements (lifetime fill transmissions going 300k+ vs. a manual that will usually need a clutch by 100-150k). The script has been completely flipped and now the only reason to get one is to say you have one excluding rare examples like the GT86/BRZ where the auto is slow and shitty. It's sad because you used to get rewarded for driving the more challenging transmission, now everything is worse and you get to risk money shifts on top of it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26309898
> sell every single produced
Because they didn't produce near enough of them. Artificially limiting supply just masks weak demand. And even if the contribution margin is positive, multiplied by too few units won't leave profit once considering the fixed costs of development and tooling.
Further, these types of hot versions are intended to produce a halo effect -- earn positive association with the brand so folks who can't/won't spend the money or deal with other tradeoffs still choose to buy a slower, cheaper version of a Corolla. If the car isn't great, it won't generate the right kind of buzz, people won't have that association, and the brand/ model family won't see a lift. Thus, the car may be slightly profitable on its own, yet not achieve it's intended purpose and therefore be considered a flop.

>>26306957
They're pretty much extinct in the rust belt. If they exist in your area and you can still get parts for them they're pretty decent trucks depending on who owned them before. The 4.3 TBI is just a 350 minus the back two cylinders so it's solid and still has some balls despite being only 160hp. The 4.3 whoretec has a lot more power but has the leaky ass spider injector which is a pain in the dick. 10ish years ago a new quality replacement was around $500 so I hate to think what they're going for now.

In todays market you could probably find one of these in good condition for cheap and rebuild the engine, tranny and suspension for half of what you're going to pay for a comparable Tacoma or Ranger.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I have a 2nd gen Blazer. First of all, almost every gasket will leak and need to be replaced around 100k miles. The transmission slips and is designed to slip from the factory. However, the 4.3 vortec long block is rock solid. If you are good at mechanical things, a few aftermarket upgrades (better intake manifold gaskets, better injector spider, etc) will make the engine way more reliable. Almost everything bolted onto the motor will fail, but most of it is easy to change and relatively cheap. Its a great running engine with a lot of torque.

The infamous 4l60e can be made into a sturdy transmission with some upgrades. Corvette servo, pinless accumulators, and a shift kit will make it a super reliable transmission.

Do your oil changes on time and dont abuse it and its a fine truck. It is not a racecar.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26281079
The more difficult part when i did the change on mine was getting the end links in. Getting the old bar out and new one in was fairly simple.
Si springs can be swapped over as well. 10mm drop, front spring rate is 7% higher (144.2lbs/in vs 126.8lbs/in) while the rears are 32% stiffer (208.8lbs/in vs 158.5lbs/in). Should help with reducing body roll/improving weight transfer, noticed with mine that it feels a bit wallowy when being pushed hard.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26281787
Yeah that was my problem lol. Ended up unbolting the endlinks from the sway bar and bolting them to the control arm first, then the sway bar. I also thought of installing Si springs to keep her OEM+ but I want a modest drop, so I'm installing Eibach Pros next week. So far I've installed a Type R shift assembly, subframe brace, DC strut bar, this sway bar, and soon the springs. I'm out of ideas for what next. Maybe brakes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26281892
Brakes are a decent choice. DC5R calipers bolt straight on to the knuckle and go well with S2000 rotors, another option would be the Genesis Coupe Brembos paired with Rogue disks. DC5 Creations has a remachined TL Type S caliper that also directly bolts on (OEM ones use an M14 bolt rather than M12), need to use the TL-S rotors for that.

They should all be plug-n-play for the most part, bias will be more towards the front but the ABS should be able to figure it out. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26308203
Rough idle could be IACV like other anon said or other sensor issue. Every engine needs spark and air/fuel in the right amounts. IACV is most probable issue, if not look for issues with air and fuel like MAP sensor, O2 sensor, BPS, vacuum leak, etc. Try to get the fault code and rule out obvious stuff like cracked vacuum hoses or a clogged air filter. Other sensors like IAT, TPS, and ignition issues generally appear under load or at higher rpm and not idle.

A lot of dealers work off of 3 major items:

Interest rates tend to be higher in times of high inflation, so financing then isn't a freebie.
Deferring payment to a future date doesn't benefit you unless you've done something else useful with the money in the mean time. Doing something else with the money means not holding onto it in cash, which means you're effectively enslaved to the lender since you have to keep income to make the payments.
Earning a higher percentage return on your money than the interest rate of the loan means taking risk. If you had done that for the past year you probably would have lost like 20% of your money in the market while also accruing interest on your loan.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26317438
>Europe wants to kill atomic
Absolutely untrue, the only reason that clean nuclear energy hasn't been the priority is that it takes too long to build old-fashioned light water reactors, and they produce too much 'waste'.
The US just approved our first modern Small Modular Reactor, and with European companies developing the same technology its not long until they roll out there as well.
They're a good fit to drop in at existing fossil fuel power plants to replace their aging generators that need to be replaced with clean energy.

Wind and Solar have gotten the majority of the focus because solar generation maps extremely well with peak demand, and wind, especially off-shore can be extremely reliable.
With pumped hydro electric, hydrogen electrolysis, flow batteries, etc over-capacity can be stored for peak generation.
Worst case scenario in the short term is wind and solar reduce the amount of fossil fuels needing to be burned, and those plants only come on as a last-ditch solution.

>I drive cheaper with gas than my neighbor on electricity (he pays over 50ct/kwh).
Sucks to be him if that's what he's paying off-peak, but that's still 4-5 miles a kWh which should translate to pretty close to what it costs a gas car to drive. If that's the kind of electrical bill you have there solar panels and home storage would be an extremely good investment.
That's just what happens when a government foolishly makes themselves dependent on foreign fossil fuels like Germany did thinking that would moderate authoritarian countries run by former KGB operatives.

>You might as well raze the entirety of European city centers and rebuild it. It would probably come out as cheaper.
Sounds like its infrastructure investment that needs to be done in your backwards country anyway. Had no problems with an EV here in the United States of America.
Might be painful short term but its still better than putting your countries balls in the hands of hostile authoritarians.

>>26313632
The stutter there kind of sounds like a weak battery. Does it just keep cranking like that without starting? Or does it stop cranking like that stutter? Have you measured the battery voltage or attached a charger?

If it'll keep cranking like that but never fire, the engine has compression I can hear so you either lack spark or fuel. Spark you can check by pulled a spark plug and using an insulated tool to hold it against something metal while you crank to see if you see spark. Fuel you can attach a pressure gauge or unhook the fuel line and put it in a jar to see if it fills while cranking. Based on what's missing you can narrow down the problem.

Rule of thumb is a car with problems is ALWAYS worse than the seller maintains it is. "Just needs an o2 sensor" translates to "engine overheated and block cracked". On a problem car, make sure to offer as if it needs major work because there's a good chance it does.

If the cat is clogged, it should be difficult to rev and there will be little exhaust coming out of the exhaust pipe when it's running, that's no guarantee that's the only problem though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26315364
Cut off the burnt tape, wrap it in new harness tape, and figure out some kind of heatshield. Metal conducts heat very well, so you need an air gap between the heat shield, simply wrapping it in metal tape won't do much. Maybe a small piece of metal with air on either side.

Possibly a small piece of sound deadening wrapped around with some zip ties could work, just monitor for melting.

Can that egr pipe be bent away a bit? even like a half inch could make a big difference. Make your fix, warm up your engine thoroughly, and use a IR heat thermometer to see if it's getting too hot.

Get a good quality crimper ($30 min) and some good quality crimps. Look on youtube for making automotive crimps for proper procedure.

It's all 12V so you can't get shocked, but always kill power or pull neg side of battery so you don't fry your electronics.

Is the audi 4.2 reliable compared with most german powerplants?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26281331
Why tho

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26284175
A lot of those older VAG engines are pretty solid, the main things to look out for on the 4.2 in particular are the intake manifold flaps (actuators tend to fail over time, making for less low-end torque) and the coil packs (which can be retrofitted for more modern ones with a simple adapter kit).
Chain-driven 4.2 40Vs are a different story (they're a nightmare), 4.2 FSIs still need the occasional major expensive service but they're less likely to slap you with it out of the blue like the chain-driven 40Vs do.

Reminder thats how the clio v6 was born.

An initial idea to drop in the turbocharged three-cylinder 12-valve engine from the Daihatsu Charade GTTi was scorched by problems mating up the electronics, but rather than scaling back his ambitions, Bruen went even wider, He began looking for a car with a wheelbase that would match the 92.3-inch (2345 mm) Twingo’s, and found one in the Ferrari 308 (92.1 inches, 2340 mm), which had a separate chassis, so theoretically could be fairly easily fused with the little Renault.


“The good thing was that the Ferrari came from a different [older] period, so the track was not that wide, whereas the Twingo, for its category was a very wide car,” remembers Breun.

But although he persuaded Renault to donate an unused Twingo shell and came close on more than one occasion to buying an accident-damaged 308 to get the project really rolling, Breun couldn’t quite pull the funds together to make it happen.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dxACf-txT48

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26301422
What do you mean?
The Libero typically only sends power to the rear axle, but the transmission allows locking the front axle to rear axle. When engaged, it's fully locked-- no speed difference allowed. So, you don't want to use it in normal grip circumstances-- you can hurt the transmission by turning on dry pavement with the front axle engaged. Putting a viscous coupling in the middle would allow the axles to move at different speed, so I could just keep the front axle engaged, drive around like normal, and the system will start locking if slippage occurs.

>>26280610
I have a few. Two in progress, one in the pipeline, and one as a pipe dream.

I have a 1989 Ramcharger body swapped onto a 1992 W250 Chassis I'm building as an off road rig. It's fully functional, pulls double duty as a farm truck and daily getting 20mpg despite 4.10 gearing and 37s. Excellent truck, 10/10, glad I went through with it. Just want to get some lockers and a roll cage so it's useable on more difficult trails.

I also have a 2012 Dodge Challenger R/T I'm getting ready to build into a full blown time attack car. Aero, suspension, extensive engine modification - more than I could reasonably list. I've had the plans for a decade, but the car has been my daily for most of that time, so going through with it hasn't been reasonable. It's my priority after I finish building my shop.

This Autumn, I plan on trailering my dad's derelict 1997 F-150 home to restore. It's just a base model long bed single cab, but it has memories attached to it. I want to rebuild the 4.9L with a little extra horsepower, but almost all the work will be in the aesthetics. Planning to do extensive bodywork and paint, two tone Pacific Green Metallic and Harvest Gold Metallic. I want to try to fit the next gen's King Ranch leather interior and also find a custom wheelmaker that can take the stock 17s and turn them into a nice 3 piece with a chrome lip and matching gold body. Really church it up into a show quality truck so I can give it back to the man who got me into cars.

Last one is a fantasy, but I really want to find a clapped 240Z and 340 Mopar swap it. I'd like to make it into a full N/A drag build, big tire with tubs and everything like a Pro Street car from the era. Even used CAD to mock up some 340Z emblems I wanted to custom make for it. It's a feasible build, but expensive due to how many S30s infested with rot and the prices hiking on clean ones, not to mention the cost of a 340 block and necessary fabrication to build it how I want.

posts.sub: How far can one push a Mazda 3?
posts.com: New to modding, just picked up a very nice 3 GT. So essentially, I wouldn’t mind losing some fuel economy for extra power. Great! posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26319283
Most places realistically will not take physical cash if its more than 5k. They don't want to deal with that shit.
They will push loans and payment plans, don't talk about how you want to pay until you get to the finance desk and have a full quote in hand.
I've bought with cashiers check, and straight debit card twice now for new bikes.

Cashiers check was
>go in
>they know im purchasing one bike in particular already
>while they're getting it ready I ask for the quote on paper
>once have quote in hand on paper inform them I'll get a cashiers check
>go to bank get cashiers check for quoted amount
>use debit card to cover any additional fees or warranty plans post-quote.

If you already know the quote and have agreed to it you can get a cashiers check for that amount ahead of time. using debit/credit card to cover any additional fees/warranty that comes up during process

For straight debit card purchase
>call in to bank
>have debit card daily limit increased to 15k for 24hrs
>when time comes to pay use debit card
>swipe and done

>>26319410
Its like a lot of people think horsepower is some kind of magical number thats pulled from the heavens, and not the result of torque(rpm). The reasons engines lose power towards redline is down to piston distance and total volume as the piston moves faster and faster. 10,000 foot view being you can imagine the piston essentially moving so fast it starts to outrun the explosion so less torque is transfered to the pistol face and crank. If a vehicle still makes more power right up to redline then the redline has been engineered to be lower than the engine can handle usually for longevities sake.

If your shit's all rusted out, you could consider either side of the cross member that the transmission sits on. I don't know why you'd want to try to jack it right in the center though. I usually go for like maybe control arm mounts in the front and like maybe the rear diff outrigger bolts in the back if it's for stands.

You act like most people interested in these cars didn't know about them in the first place. There's a finite amount of people interested in resurrecting a shitbox vs. buying a new(er) car. Cash for Clunkers wasn't it, either, they just scrapped a bunch of garbage SUVs and land barges, barely any economy or desirable sports cars were scrapped.

The real reason the 80's and 90's shitboxes are getting expensive is because:
-people went through them like toilet paper in the early 00's ignoring maintenance, ragging the hell out of them, and eventually wrapping them around a tree. It's hard to care about a car you bought for $500.
-any car owned North of Texas and East of Las Vegas will turn a car to dust in 5-10 years

So between rust, neglect, and sheer abuse there are only a handful of these cars left in any condition, let alone *good* condition.

There's also the fact that people later learned that 90's cars wouldn't die shortly after 100k miles like cars made in the 70's and before if not immaculately cared for, so now people know a car with even 200k miles still has life left and prices accordingly.

The future of affordable car enthusiasm is in former Boomer garage queens that were the Beanie Babies for Boomers. Every Boomer bought a C5 Corvette and treated it like a precious gemstone awaiting for the day it would be worth 5x its original value, but they ALL did that and now a pristine one is worth $20k or less and a driven but completely usable one is $10k. Stop being a dumb weeb and just get a Corvette already, they're honestly some of the best driver's cars ever made and your hatred of Boomers has kept you from realizing this.

>>26311354
all valid points
imo it's size you get used to, it's not as big as it seems, it's just long and has wide haunches, the track width is not much larger than a civic.
the trunk slopes away from the window, it's better to roll down a window or open the door and look behind you. Also the car is square so you merely need to line its sides up with a parking space and back in.
the GT is an SXT with Scat Pack R/T suspension and exterior trim. Did you get an AWD one? They weigh a bit more and have the taller Police Pursuit AWD suspension instead so they are more boaty.

New V6 Challies are (were) 28-30k, the "GT RWD" is just a renaming of the existing Super Track Pack option plus the SRT bumper and hood.
You can buy them used for ridiculously cheap, they have a famously reliable engine and trans and all the parts support from the big engine trims. Despite being a comparatively massive car the V6 Chally actually has the same weight distribution as the ND Miata and a superior power-to-weight ratio. It compares strongly against Japanese and Euro sports coupes half it's size and displacement.

I would also say that the V6 model is not aimed at enthusiasts whatsoever. The auto trans cannot even throttle blip itself without an electronic hack. It is the LX platform and the Mopar business model that makes it an enthusiast car, by itself it's just a glorified taxi.
A stock V6 Chally off the lot is a dog. It has an open diff ffs. However they are so easily modded and take to improvements so well it's a wonder anyone even drives them stock.

I bought this car knowing they have a slow and boaty reputation, and I am simply excited to post about how the lowly base model Chally Wally with a minivan engine has exceeded all my expectations and continues to defy haters' predictions. The Pentastar loves to have the tits revved off of it and is completely overbuilt for the pedestrian cars it is normally installed in. The piddly 305 horsepower it makes as it slams into it's rev limiter like a special ed kid against a glass door is but a mere fraction of it's retard strength. The ZF8 has the same gear ratios as the V8 and if you can get a delimited Texas car like mine (look for High Speed Engine Controller in the build sheet) it will casually stroll to 165 mph and still have a couple gears left.
My pauper spec car endeared itself to me. I did my research, took a leap and bought it. I only post to encourage /o/ posters that the Challenger is a great car in all it's specs, the LX chassis is the last of the 'old school' and you should totally motherfucking buy one, any one, right now before you can't anymore.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26317551
pretty much as
>>26317623
posted
the cars are made with mostly all the same electronics but different features enabled in software depending on trim level and engine.
V6 cars have a different internal product code than the V8s which allows other variables to be set or not. For example the ZF8HP45 can actually do the gear-binding launch control the V8 trans can but the V6 product code overrides that capability. If you use HP tuners you can modify the product code and enable it, you'd basically do the same basic procedure to swap a hellcat into an sxt, although it'll still need actual map tuning to run right. You can also just get the ECU out of the V8 donor and reprogram the VIN to the swap car.

>>26317761
yes both engines are super reliable, the transmissions are too but you have to keep up with maintenance. A recommended mod for both engines is a 180 degree thermostat that keeps the entire powertrain much cooler.

Whats the tuning path for the v6? Turbo? super charger?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26318375
Hellcat or SRT LSD and the 180 deg tstat first up, Hellcat airbox, lower intake manifold out of the 17+ Pacifica/Durango, better coil packs, bore out the throttle body or get an adapter to fit the Hemis tb, a catch can for both sides, ECU tune for 91, then you get the Ripp centrifugal s/c for about 450 WHP and some change.
Swapping the open diff for a limited slip is definitely the number one best thing you can do to a Chally. For a 15+ V6 you will need left and right axles from a 5.7 R/T and the hellcat's diff pumpkin, for the older models you can actually buy and swap the entire fucking rear subframe from a 2015+, or get the SRT8 diff (rarer than the later ZF units but also tougher). ZF diffs are lighter and come in a greater range of ratios. Ofc Charger and 300C parts will also fit the Chally.
All manny Challies have the LSD too, easiest way to get one.

>>26304518
everything everyone else said, but two more things:

1. Cops love to put speed traps at the bottom of hills so you can't see them before it's too late. Always slow down before you crest hills on the interstate, or at least be prepared to slam on the brakes

2. If you don't see a cop until it's too late and you pass him while doing way over the speed limit, DO NOT HIT YOUR BRAKES IF YOU CAN AVOID IT. If you have a handbrake, gently pull on that to slow down. Cops often look for incriminating brakelights to aim their guns at because it's easier than gunning every car that drives by. Also, if they do ticket you, if your brake lights never come on and by the time they catch up to you you're doing the speed limit, the dashcam footage will often be enough to get a judge to throw out your ticket.

For those that don't know, the 351's came with a Variable Venturi carb and controlled by an MCU (Mixture Control Unit). These are real pick-up trucks, made in an age before driving a pickup was some sort of class/political/fashion statement.

The people that needed pickups owned pickups, and everyone else drove a sedan/wagon/hatch/coupe back then.

The pickup was a practical and durable all steel vehicle for the self-employed, industrial and commercial use.

The outdoorsy type used to have these things called “RVs” or slide-in campers.

“RVs” were self-propelled campers that could haul the daily driver or Jeep behind them.

The portable McMansion pull behind campers that you see today simply weren’t a thing. And I’ve never met a serious outdoorsmen that owned one.

M60 can hit 300kmh too easy as long as it's geared correctly and you have an auto differential as they tend to be geared much lower than manual ones.
Might run out of grunt past 250kmh though and need a long straight to get to 300kmh, it's not THAT much weaker than the M70 on paper, but it does run out of steam much faster than the M70 that keeps on chugging with pretty much full torque from idle till redline

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

>>26311009
Also also, the M70 has a 4 speed ZF4HP24, which is just a beefed up variant of the infamous 4HP22, one of the worst autotragic slushboxes ever made, legendary for frying itself when left idling due to shit horrible design and shitty gaskets.
ZF made this tranny for a good few decades and NEVER fixed the issue in the 22, they did fix it for the 24, but fuck me if they could be bothered to do jack shit for the 22.
That being said I've been beating on the auto for a good while now and it's not even slipping yet despite burnouts, drifting and a ton of V12 powered hooning.
Even if it blew, I just might rebuild it or get a new one as I've really started liking it for some reason, although I'd rather have the 5 speed 5HP30 from the M60 behind the M70, that would be tops, but I'm not that good at cars to do the swap due to it being electronically controlled unlike the mainly mechanical 4HP series

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
another thing about forward acceleration: your perception of it is highly inaccurate. probably, because you actually "feel" some derivative of acceleration, not acceleration itself which is just the feeling of muscle tension. Saying a car is better because it has a lower 0-60 time is like saying a wine is better because it has a higher ABV.
Case and point: when you are on a commercial flight taking off, it feels like it's accelerating fast but it's actually accelerating as slow as a bus. It only feels that way because of how different thrust vs traction works, and creates larger higher order derivatives of speed than 99% of wheeled vehicles ever will

>>26309594
>the new oil cooler doesn't do anything though
This is wrong though.
>>26309614
>it does do something, it’s actually very helpful for getting the oil up to temperature faster
This is true because the "oil cooler" in question is really just a heat exchanger between the oil and coolant. The coolant tends to heat up faster than the oil does because of all the hot parts it's working through but once the motor is up to temperature, oil temperatures can continue to increase and in this case, the exchanger works to keep the oil temperatures lower although it can only do so much.

For reference, under track conditions, I've seen bone stock first gen owners report peak coolant temps at 215-230f and peak oil temps at 265-290f. The reports I've seen from bone stock 2nd gen owners on track indicate peak coolant temperatures reaching 210-220f and peak oil temperatures reaching 240-250f so it's pretty clear to me that the coolant system in the new car is definitely more robust.

posts.com:
Audi is better than Porsche. Audi saved Porsche with its MLB platform and V6 and V8 that underpins the majority of Porsches sales.
Ignoring this Audis RS5 a much better car than it’s equivalent the 911 C2S.

>Audi understeers
So does a 911.
The fact is that Porsche is overpriced normie hype these days. The 996 M97 engine was the start. It’s a cheap bad engine with many flaws and it was designed for light commuting as evidenced by its poorly designed ‘dry sump’. Porsche knew it was bad and used the old Metzger for the serious 911s. Porsche managed to keep this facade going with the bore scoring ims failing piece of shit engines for over a decade before they moved on to direct injection (Audi innovation btw). And the 911 hasn’t come with an LSD below the GT3/Turbo trim since 1998.

911s below GT3 have McDonald struts. Even a basic bitch A4 has a more sophisticated system.

The 991 awd models use a Haldex.

The 911 has always been an every man’s sports car so some of these deficiencies are just 911 heritage. But. What’s changed is the cost. A 911 used to be an easily affordable choice for a middle class income similar to a corvette. Instead 911 now costs $110k starting before nickel and diming options start.

Buy a Camaro. Buy an S5, buy an M4, buy a mustang, buy a corvette. There is no case for the 911 relative to the competition except for vanity

>>26317116
Good that you do, you already made clear your opinion is worthless.
>>26317074
>e46 coupe
>petrol/lng
Avoid the later 4pot engines - timing chain issues, early valvetronic and the like are not fun to deal with. The early 4cyl. are simple, pretty gutless and like leaking oil and coolant - which is not a hard fix "most" of the time. 6pots are generally fine, but many may have been abused. You have to inspect it on a lift and look if the rear axle mounts are damaged - especially on an early model. It is fixable, but not really something you want to deal with. Also obvious old car stuff like looking for rust crash damage etc.
>5th gen Prelude
Everybody I knew who had one was a dumbfuck who abused it because "lul its a honda they can take it". Especially body parts are expensive and hard to get. Generally somewhat reliable, but one of the more problematic Hondas out there. The H series may burn oil and you have to find somebody who knows about them to fix it. They like to rust.
>7th gen accord
You will get the K20 or K24. Probably the safest choice on the list and really good engines.
>volvo s40/s60
nice ford
>Celica
Last gen burns oil and isn't good at anything, earlier models really depends on the gen
>hyoondie coupe
Stay away from old Korean cars
Honestly I would either look for the 7th gen Accord, or a well kept E46 coupe. For the latter, be sure that your mechanic knows his stuff about old BMW. Just make sure that you don't get a clapped out shitheap.

The main driver of people buying/building powerwalls or investing into solar is that the grid where you live isn't reliable.
It doesn't matter if its being unable to hire people to clear away trees around the cables, reliability problems for the power plants, or problems with the upkeep for the transformators or transfer lines.

The second driver is even simpler: What happens when Solar drops below the cost of buying the same power from grid over 10-15 years, and the panels are expected to last 30-50 years?
But the second can't happen without the first.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26316660
I live in British Columbia, so take my experience as you will... I was the executor of a will, and two vehicles registered in my name at that time I had gifted to two different people. One extended family, one not. Both vehicles book value @ $10,000. These were literal gifts, as I had accepted no cash for executing this will. The first vehicle transferred to a family member, he had later received a letter stating he owed taxes based on book market value of vehicle. The second vehicle transferred to the other guy, never received such notice, although I'm sure they could have required him to pay tax also. So here, they do retain the power to tax the new buyer @ book price, even though not a single fucking cent changed hands. In my case, it was 50/50 here, with one having to pay tax on a vehicle that was already taxed when bought new, and one not having to pay. Obviously I never inquired exactly why one had to pay, and the other did not, so I have no clue as to how that's handled on their end.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26316667
>what form?
NY DMV form dtf-802, which the seller is required to sign if the vehicle is a gift or sold below market value otherwise they don't accept the new owner saying it's a gift as truthful and will charge the new owner tax on what they consider fair market value when they go to register it, because registration and inspection are also invalidated upon a title transfer in NY

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

posts.name: Anonymous

You pay the taxes upon registration. So it doesn’t matter what state the car came from or was previously registered under, the state and county you live in will decide what taxes you pay on the sale.
